+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Music Listeners Test 128kbps vs. 256kbps AAC                       |
|   from the perfect-pitches dept.                                   |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Thursday May 31, @20:22 (Media (Apple))  |
|   http://apple.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/31/2243206        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

notthatwillsmith writes "Maximum PC did [0]double-blind testing with ten
listeners in order to determine whether or not normal people could
discern the quality difference between the new 256kbps iTunes Plus files
and the old, DRM-laden 128kbps tracks. But wait, there's more! To add an
extra twist, they also tested Apple's default iPod earbuds vs. an
expensive pair of Shure buds to see how much of an impact earbud quality
had on the detection rate."

Discuss this story at:
    http://apple.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/05/31/2243206

Links:
    0. http://www.maximumpc.com/article/itunes_256_vs_128_bit


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Launch Date Announced for Shuttle Mission STS-117                  |
|   from the back-in-the-saddle dept.                                |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Thursday May 31, @21:48 (NASA)           |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/31/2313212      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]chuckpeters writes "After a two day Flight Readiness Review in
Florida, space shuttle managers have announced an [1]official launch date
for STS-117 to be June 8, 7:38 PM. The launch window will run in two
parts \u2014 from June 8th to the evening of June 12th when the shuttle must
stand down for a June 14th Atlas launch. After that the windows opens
again on the 17th. This first opening gives the standard four attempts in
five days. If they have not launched by the 12th, they will replenish
things such as liquid oxygen and hydrogen for the fuel cells to prepare
for the 17th attempt."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/05/31/2313212

Links:
    0. http://starryskies.net/
    1. http://starryskies.net/articles/2007/05/STS-117_lda/STS-117_launch_date_announced.php


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| New Anti-Forensics Tools Thwart Police                             |
|   from the knowing-thine-enemy dept.                               |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Thursday May 31, @22:15 (Security)       |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/31/2338203          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]rabblerouzer writes "Antiforensic tools have slid down the technical
food chain, from Unix to Windows, from something only elite users could
master to something nontechnical users can operate. 'Five years ago, you
could count on one hand the number of people who could do a lot of these
things,' says one investigator. '[1]Now it's hobby level.' Take, for
example, TimeStomp. Forensic investigators poring over compromised
systems where Timestomp was used often find files that were created 10
years from now, accessed two years ago and never modified."

Discuss this story at:
    http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/05/31/2338203

Links:
    0. http://www.cio.com/
    1. http://www.cio.com/article/114550


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| EMI, YouTube Strike Music Video Deal                               |
|   from the ebony-and-ivory dept.                                   |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Thursday May 31, @23:38 (Google)         |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/0032248              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]eldavojohn writes "Despite [1]initial complaints of copyright
infringement, EMI is now [2]striking a deal with YouTube. Perhaps they've
noticed that [3]Warner's deal has boded well or they've finally come
around to free marketing? From the article, "EMI and YouTube have agreed
to work together to develop ways in which EMI-owned recordings can be
incorporated into user generated content by YouTube users. News of the
deal comes just 10 days after EMI agreed to be taken over by private
equity group Terra Firma for £2.4bn." YouTube is slowing building a cadre
of friends on the playground while Viacom continues to [4]bully the new
kid."

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/0032248

Links:
    0. http://barsukmusic.blaireau.net/menomena/
    1. http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=06/09/15/009257&tid=97
    2. http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6709209.stm
    3. http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=06/09/18/1046247&tid=129
    4. http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/03/13/1413242&tid=217


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| 10 Anti-Phishing Firefox Extensions                                |
|   from the lock-the-windows dept.                                  |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Friday June 01, @01:12 (Mozilla)         |
|   http://it.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/016208            |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "A list of [0]10 anti-phishing Firefox
extensions was published at Security-Hacks: 'For most Internet users,
defending against phishing attacks is a top priority. One popular way to
combat phishing attacks is to maintain a list of known phishing sites and
to check web sites against the list.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://it.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/016208

Links:
    0. http://www.security-hacks.com/2007/05/31/10-anti-phishing-firefox-extensions


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| TurboLinux to Sell Wizpy Media Player Worldwide                    |
|   from the rocking-tux-on-the-go dept.                             |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Friday June 01, @04:09 (TurboLinux)      |
|   http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/0512200        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

MsManhattan writes "TurboLinux will attempt to lure Windows users over to
the Linux operating system in baby steps this June when it [0]starts
selling its Wizpy media player worldwide. The pocket-sized device, which
plays audio and video files, is really a Linux carrot of sorts, in that
it also allows users to store a complete Linux desktop in its memory. You
can plug the Wizpy into a PC's USB port and boot up the Linux system with
all its user settings, passwords, bookmarks, etc. It originally launched
in Japan, where TurboLinux marketed it to 'early adopters who are curious
about using Linux but either don't want to or can't install the operating
system.' The company will now target the same crowd around the globe,
starting in the U.S., the U.K., Australia, India and Singapore."

Discuss this story at:
    http://linux.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/0512200

Links:
    0. http://open.itworld.com/4906/070531wizpy/page_1.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| FSF Releases Fourth and Final Draft of GPLv3                       |
|   from the wading-through-legalese dept.                           |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Friday June 01, @07:19 (GNU is Not Unix) |
|   http://apache.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/055243        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "The most notable changes found in this latest
draft include [0]making GPLv3 compatible with version 2.0 of the Apache
license, ensuring that distributors who make discriminatory patent deals
after March 28 may not convey software under GPLv3, adding terms to
clarify how users can contract for private modification of free software
or for a data center to run it for them, and replacing the previous
reference to a U.S. consumer protection statute with explicit criteria
for greater clarity outside the United States. The draft also does not
prohibit Novell from distributing software under GPLv3 'because the
patent protection they arranged with Microsoft last November can be
turned against Microsoft to the community's benefit,' FSF executive
director Peter Brown said."

Discuss this story at:
    http://apache.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/055243

Links:
    0. http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,1895,2139806,00.asp


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Google Street View Raises Privacy Concerns                         |
|   from the we-see-everybody-now dept.                              |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @08:42 (Privacy)               |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1219256          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]Pcol writes "The New York Times is running a story about a woman who
says [1]her cat is clearly visible through the living room window of her
second-floor apartment using Street View and that she has contacted
Google asking that [2]the photo be removed. 'The issue that I have
ultimately is about where you draw the line between taking public photos
and zooming in on people's lives,' Ms. Kalin-Casey said in an interview.
'The next step might be seeing books on my shelf. If the government was
doing this, people would be outraged.' Wired has started a contest on the
[3]most interesting photos found using the new Google Tool that now
includes sunbathing coeds, alleged drug deals, and the google van itself.
'I think that this product illustrates a tension between our First
Amendment right to document public spaces around us, and the privacy
interests people have as they go about their day,' says Kevin Bankston, a
staff lawyer at the Electronic Frontier Foundation."

Discuss this story at:
    http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1219256

Links:
    0. http://peacecorpsonline.org/
    1. http://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/01/technology/01private.html
    2. http://maps.google.com/?ie=UTF8&om=1&layer=c&cbll=37.810337%2C-122.252508&cbp=1%2C273.618658414742%2C0.372247067615998%2C3&ll=37.812056%2C-122.252276&spn=0.014664%2C0.014398&z=16
    3. http://blog.wired.com/27bstroke6/2007/05/request_for_urb.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| New AACS Fix Hacked in a Day                                       |
|   from the oh-day-warr-ez dept.                                    |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @09:22 (Hardware Hacking)      |
|   http://hardware.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1245251     |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]VincenzoRomano writes "ArsTechnica has just published an [1]update to
the neverending story about copy protection used in HD DVD and Blu-ray
discs and hacker efforts against it. From the article: 'The ongoing war
between content producers and hackers over the AACS copy protection used
in HD DVD and Blu-ray discs produced yet another skirmish last week, and
as has been the case as of late, the hackers came out on top. The hacker
BtCB posted the new decryption key for AACS on the Freedom to Tinker web
site, just one day after the AACS Licensing Authority (AACS LA) issued
the key.' The article proposes a simple description of the protection
schema and a brief look back at how the cracks have slowly chipped away
at its effectiveness. It seems it'll be a long way to an effective
solution ... if any. One could also argue whether all that money spent by
the industry in this race will be worth the results and how long it would
take for a return on investment."

Discuss this story at:
    http://hardware.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1245251

Links:
    0. mailto:vincenzo.romano@gmail.com
    1. http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20070531-new-aacs-fix-hacked-in-a-day.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Intel Shows Off 80-core Processor                                  |
|   from the next-up-a-skillion-core-system dept.                    |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @10:03 (Intel)                 |
|   http://hardware.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/135253      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

thejakebrain writes "Intel has built its [0]80-core processor as part of
a research project, but don't expect it on your desktop any time soon.
The company's CTO, Justin Rattner, held a demonstration of the chip for a
group of reports last week. Intel will be presenting a paper on the
project at the International Solid State Circuits Conference in San
Francisco this week. 'The chip is capable of producing 1 trillion
floating-point operations per second, known as a teraflop. That's a level
of performance that required 2,500 square feet of large computers a
decade ago. Intel first disclosed it had built a prototype 80-core
processor during last fall's Intel Developer Forum, when CEO Paul
Otellini promised to deliver the chip within five years.'" Update: 06/01
14:37 GMT by [1]Z : This article is about four months old. We
[2]discussed this briefly last year, but search didn't show that we
discussed in February.

Discuss this story at:
    http://hardware.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/135253

Links:
    0. http://news.com.com/Intel+shows+off+80-core+processor/2100-1006_3-6158181.html
    1. http://slashdot.org/~Zonk/
    2. http://hardware.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=06/09/26/1937237&tid=118


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Indecent Game Sales Now A Felony In New York                       |
|   from the watch-your-back-citizen dept.                           |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @10:34 (The Courts)            |
|   http://games.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1433218        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

Gamespot reports on the final passing of New York senate bill A8696,
legislation proposed just last week, that now makes it [0]a serious
felony to sell or rent a violent game to minors. The bill makes it
illegal to sell a console without parental control options and
establishes a group to second guess the ESRB's rating decisions. "'This
bill is impermissibly vague,' EMA president Bo Andersen said in a
statement. 'A8696 seeks to apply real-world standards of violence to the
fictional and fanciful world of video games, an environment in which they
have no meaning. As a result, retailers and clerks will not and cannot
know with certainty which video games could send them to jail under
A8696. It was depressing to hear members of the Assembly note the
constitutional problems with the bill and then state that they were
voting for it.'" The senate seems to have no fear of possible overturn of
the bill, and claims it's only thinking of the children.

Discuss this story at:
    http://games.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1433218

Links:
    0. http://www.gamespot.com/news/6171789.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Canadian Movie Camcording Addressed With Legislation               |
|   from the cameras-down dept.                                      |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @11:01 (Media)                 |
|   http://politics.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1424200     |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

dottyslashdottydot writes "During Arnold Schwarzenegger's visit to Ottawa
yesterday, it was confirmed that Prime Minister Stephen Harper will be
introducing [0]a bill to make camcording in movie theatres illegal in
Canada. However, [1]people are skeptical that this will make little
difference in the amount of pirated movies available. Spie Frith,
president of the Canadian Motion Picture Distributors Association was
quoted as saying, 'is really the first step \u2014 not only for the movie
industry \u2014 where the government has shown it will [2]seriously address
the whole area of intellectual-property theft.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://politics.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1424200

Links:
    0. http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2007/05/31/harper-schwarzenegger.html
    1. http://www.michaelgeist.ca/content/view/1992/125/
    2. http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070530.wpiracy05301/BNStory/National/home


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Battlestar Galactica's End Officially After Season 4               |
|   from the on-their-own-terms-is-better-than-the-alternative dept. |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @11:45 (Television)            |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1450248              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]Ant writes "First [1]it was off, and then [2]it was back on. Yahoo is
now reporting on a release put out by David Eick and Ronald Moore stating
that they will [3]conclude Battlestar Galactica at the end of Season 4.
They said it was a creative decision, and that they wanted to end the
show on their own terms. The show was always planned with a definite
beginning, middle and end, unlike many other sci-fi shows and dramas. Sci
Fi Channel has accepted the decision. The news had been foreshadowed this
spring through statements from stars Edward James Olmos and Katee
Sackhoff. Ronald Moore himself had said that the show was heading into
its final act, although he said the final act could be one or two more
seasons. Now we know that the final act will last for one season. The
special 2-hr. episode 'Razor' starts off the season in November. The
first regular episodes of Season 4 will air in early 2008."

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1450248

Links:
    0. http://aqfl.net/
    1. http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/11/158218&tid=129
    2. http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/12/1247256&tid=214
    3. http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20070601/tv_nm/battlestar_dc


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Microsoft vs TestDriven.NET                                        |
|   from the stop-trying-to-help dept.                               |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @12:22 (Microsoft)             |
|   http://developers.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/164254    |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

Erebus writes "Jamie Cansdale released a free addin to Visual Studio back
in 2004 to [0]help developers build unit tests. His only problem was, he
enable his addin for all versions of VS - including the Express addition
which isn't suppose to support addins. After over a year of trying to
talk with Microsoft and understand how and [1]why he was in violation of
their license agreement, during which they would never explain
specifically which clause in the license was being violate, they sent the
lawyers after him and pulled his MVP status. To top it all off, Jamie is
actually a Java developer by day, his addin was originally developed just
as a hobby project. A [2]full account is available on his blog,
[3]including all email correspondence he had with Microsoft and the now 3
letters received from Microsoft lawyers. The [1]lead product manager for
Visual Studio Express has responded to Jamie's posts."

Discuss this story at:
    http://developers.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/164254

Links:
    0. http://testdriven.net/
    1. http://blogs.msdn.com/danielfe/archive/2007/05/31/visual-studio-express-and-testdriven-net.aspx
    2. http://weblogs.asp.net/nunitaddin/default.aspx
    3. http://weblogs.asp.net/nunitaddin/archive/2007/05/30/microsoft-vs-testdriven-net-express.aspx


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| DVR Viewers Push Ad Ratings Higher                                 |
|   from the future-is-now dept.                                     |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @13:05 (Television)            |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1626245              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "It looks like DVRs and timeshifting has
finally done what many people said it would do: [0]increased overall
viewership! USA Today reports: 'Among the things the report revealed is
that many DVR viewers do not fast-forward through ads. The viewer total
for broadcast network ads goes up 32% when DVR watchers within three days
are included, according to Nielsen. For some prime-time shows, it means
that DVR viewing, long seen as a threat to advertising, could even bring
higher ad prices. NBC's The Office, for example, had a live-plus-three
Nielsen commercial rating of 3.36 \u2014 higher than the 3.11 it got for the
week of May 6 under the traditional Nielsen program rating system.' Makes
me wonder where this will lead for my favorite genre shows which by their
very nature have a [1]higher DVR component and have seen declining
viewership using the older methodology (BSG, SG-1, etc)."

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1626245

Links:
    0. http://www.usatoday.com/money/media/2007-06-01-nielsens-usat_N.htm
    1. http://www.multichannel.com/article/CA6332083.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Lord of the Rings Online Review                                    |
|   from the you-got-your-hobbit-in-my-mmog dept.                    |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @13:44 (Role Playing (Games))  |
|   http://games.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/0816244        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

The circle is now complete. With Turbine's release of Lord of the Rings
Online: The Shadows of Angmar (LOTRO), the Massively Mutliplayer game
figuratively eats the tail of its originator in ouroboros-like fashion.
Tolkien's work begat Dungeons and Dragons, the PC gaming market, CRPGs,
and finally Massive games, and last month's release of LOTRO beautifully
reconnects the future with the past. Replacing dice-wielding friends
around a table has even, wonder of wonders, been done well. Polished
gameplay and cutting-edge graphics abound; In direct contrast to the
lackluster response to Turbine's other MMOG, Dungeons and Dragons Online,
Lord of the Rings Online has had an overwhelmingly positive reaction from
fans. Read on for my notes from the experience of trying on Hobbit feet
for a month, and a few words about why LOTRO's quality is notable and
highly encouraging.

This story continues at:
    http://games.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/0816244

Discuss this story at:
    http://games.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/0816244


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| 'Eolas' Browser Plug-in Patent Case Rises Again                    |
|   from the return-of-the-living-patent-case dept.                  |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @14:21 (Patents)               |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1630206          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]eldavojohn writes "A legal battle that has been around since 1999 and
[1]seemingly ended in 2005 now [2]rears its head again. In a confusing
move, the USPTO 'reissued a Microsoft patent last week covering the same
concepts outlined in the Eolas patent and with wording mirroring that of
the Eolas patent. With both companies holding identical patents, the
USPTO will now play King Solomon and decide which parent gets custody of
the baby.' Both the [3]Microsoft & [4]Eolas patents are available
online."

Discuss this story at:
    http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1630206

Links:
    0. http://barsukmusic.blaireau.net/menomena/
    1. http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=05/12/03/1436225&tid=113
    2. http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20070531-uspto-gives-microsoft-chance-to-overturn-eolas-browser-plug-in-patent.html
    3. http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-adv.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&d=PTXT&p=1&p=1&S1=((microsoft.ASNM.+AND+20070529.PD.)+AND+embed)&OS=AN/microsoft+AND+ISD/20070529+AND+embed&RS=((AN/microsoft+AND+ISD/20070529)+AND+embed)
    4. http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-adv.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&d=PTXT&p=1&p=1&S1=eolas.ASNM.&OS=AN/eolas&RS=AN/eolas


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| 'Pirates' Outsells 'Matrix' in High-Def Showdown                   |
|   from the i-thought-it-was-supposed-to-be-ninjas-not-kung-fu dept.|
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @15:06 (Media)                 |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1846210              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "As Slashdot recently reported, last week saw
the latest [0]showdown between HD DVD and Blu-ray, with both formats
bringing out the big guns in terms of high profile format-exclusive disc
releases. In one corner were the Blu-ray exclusive releases of the first
two 'Pirates of the Caribbean' films on Blu-ray \u2014 in the other, the HD
DVD exclusive releases of 'The Matrix' Trilogy. So who won the sales
battle? According to preliminary estimates, [1]this one goes to 'Pirates'
in a big way. The two 'Pirates' flicks sold an estimated 47,000 units,
while the 'Matrix' sets sold just about 13,900 units. Is this an
indication of movie quality, or another notch in the belt for the Blu-ray
format?"

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1846210

Links:
    0. http://www.highdefdigest.com/news/show/Pirates_Outsells_Matrix_in_Blu-ray,_HD_DVD_Showdown/675
    1. http://www.highdefdigest.com/news/show/675


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Venezuela's Contrarian TV Station Survives on YouTube              |
|   from the politics-plus-interweb dept.                            |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @15:41 (Television)            |
|   http://politics.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1929229     |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

carlos_J writes "Ars Technica is running a story about [0]RCTV, a
Venezuelan television station whose broadcast license was refused renewal
by the government. In response, [1]the station turned to YouTube to get
its message out. Says Ars, 'El Observador clips have been seen 175,000
times since May 28, and the channel is currently the most-subscribed
channel of the week. While putting the station's shows on YouTube is an
excellent idea, YouTube still lacks anything near the reach of
over-the-air broadcasts. But the use of the site to avoid censorship is
growing, and it's not hard to imagine a day in the near future when the
site (or sites like it) becomes as essential as local TV stations. As
that happens, YouTube will come into even more conflicts with governments
that have an interest in controlling what their citizens see, It's
already happening--Thailand's king, for instance, has a thing for iPods
but isn't too keen on YouTube. Will Hugo Chavez show more tolerance? '"

|   from the dire-straights dept.                                    |

+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

maeveth writes "Talk about not a good time to be working in the tech
sector. Layoffs all over the industry have been announced, in a variety
of different areas. Last week Dell announced they were partnering with
Wal-Mart; this week they are planning a [0]ten-percent reduction in their
global workforce. Motorola was already going to cut some 3500 jobs by the
end of June; they're now [1]adding another 4000 pink slips to that number
(and hoping that next month's RAZR2 launch will boost profits). To top it
all off Circuit City is acting in a decidedly schizophrenic manner. The
are going to [2]axe about 850 employees, on top of the 70 stores they
closed last month ... while also planning to open 165 new stores."

+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Zero Day Hole in Google Desktop                                    |
|   from the please-stop-the-internet-from-leaking dept.             |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @17:47 (Google)                |
|   http://it.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/2050252           |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

40by40 writes "A Web application security specialist has figured out a
way to [0]launch man-in-the-middle attacks against a computer with a
fully patched Google Desktop installed. With knowledge of the Google
Desktop security model (a combination of one-time tokens, iFrames and
JavaScript), hacker Robert Hansen figured out a way to sit between a
target launching a Google search query and manipulate the search results
to take control of other programs on the desktop. From the article: 'This
should drive home the point that deep integration between the desktop and
the web is not a good idea, without tremendous thought put into the
security model. As Google's site is unencrypted, and they place their
content that can run executables on their site, it can be subverted by an
attacker," Hansen warns. Hansen's advisory come just days after a Chris
Soghoian's exposé of a similar man-in-the-middle attack scenario against
a remote vulnerability in the upgrade mechanism used by a number of
commercial Firefox extensions.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://it.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/2050252

| 40% Efficiency Solar Cells Developed                               |
|   from the that-makes-me-28-percent-happy dept.                    |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @18:28 (Power)                 |
|   http://hardware.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/216215      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

gtada writes "A story published at Physorg.com discusses recently
published research into [0]the fabrication of solar cells that surpass
the 40% efficiency milestone. Such devices would be the high water-mark
to date, and hint at the possibility of even more effective technology.
'In the design, multijunction cells divide the broad solar spectrum into
three smaller sections by using three subcell band gaps. Each of the
subcells can capture a different wavelength range of light, enabling each
subcell to efficiently convert that light into electricity. With their
conversion efficiency measured at 40.7%, the metamorphic multijunction
concentrator cells surpass the theoretical limit of 37% of
single-junction cells at 1000 suns, due to their multijunction
structure.'"

    http://hardware.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/216215

+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Scientists Identify How the Body Senses Cold                       |
|   from the bit-chilly-for-me dept.                                 |
|   posted by Zonk on Friday June 01, @19:30 (Biotech)               |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/01/1548232      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

Vicissidude writes with a link to a story on the Nature website,
discussing the discovery of a protein that may [0]enable us to sense cold
temperatures. It's been pinned down in mice, and the same protein may
perform a similar function in humans. Mice rely on a single protein,
called TRPM8, to sense both cold temperatures and menthol, the compound
that gives mints their cool sensation. The sensor also controls the
pain-relieving effect of cool temperatures, but does not seem to play an
important role in the response to painfully cold temperatures below 10 C.
TRPM8 is in the same family as the protein that detects heat and
capsaicin, the compound that makes peppers hot. These proteins lie in the
cell membranes of select neurons, and form channels that open and close
in response to external signals."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/01/1548232
